respStmt.resp: Transcribed from images of original letters
respStmt.name: Sarah Tew
Giuliano Sidro
Millie You
Maddie Qualls

publicationStmt.distributor: The Center for the Tebtunis Papyri, The University of California, Berkeley
publicationStmt.authority: The Board of Trinity College Dublin, The University of Dublin

availability.p: Available for academic research purposes only.

objectDesc.p: Handwritten letter on one large rectangular sheet folded in half. All four pages created have handwritten texts on them.
Catalog number "90" written in pencil. Previous number corrected to "90".

recordHist.p: Images taken from Trinity College, Dublin: Page 1Pages 2-3Page 4

projectDesc.p: This document was created as part of the History of Papyrology project [https://histpap.info/] by Sarah Tew, Giuliano Sidro, Maddie Qualls, and Millie You. The project is in affiliation the Center for Tebtunis Papyri at the University of California, Berkeley.

editorialDecl.p: Text has been transcribed diplomatically without corrections, normalization, or standardization.

punctuation.p: All punction marks have been retained nd represented using the appropriate Unicode code character except for apostrophes and ampersands which have been escaped using ' and &, respectively.

segmentation.p: The text has been segmented into lines according to line breaks in the original text automatically by Transkribus and line groupings based on groups identified automatically or manually declared by Sarah Tew in Transkribus. Page breaks have been manually edited by Sarah Tew, Giuliano Sidro, Maddie Qualls, and Millie You after export from Transkribus.

handNotes.handNote: Written in black ink by B.P. Grenfell.

revisionDesc.change: Manually added TEI header to Transkribus tei.xml exported file.

body.ab:
My dear Smyly,
I was away in town yesterday, but
went to the Bodleian today, the light being none
of the best. Here are the answers to your queries
(1) P.P.II vii line 7. I read ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Ï„Î¿Ï…Ï„Î¿ for
ÎµÎº Ï„Î¿Ï… Î³Ì… ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ is quite certain. Î Î±Ï…Î½Î¹ in
M's copy isnt right.
line 11. the first symbol á¿what is this symbol? seems to represent
Î±ÏÎ¿Ï…ÏÎ±, the second 5unsure artabae
13. I dont understand the symbol îš.
îš is of course Î¹Ï€(Ï€Î±ÏÏ‡Î¹Î±) or some other
derivative of á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Ï‚. But here the symbol seems
to be Îœ not Î with an Î™ through the middle.
(2) P II. viii col II verso the word before
Ï„Î¹ÏÎ±Ï‡Î¸Î·ÏƒÎ¿Î½Ï„Î±Î¹ might be read as ÎµÌ£Ï€Ì£ÎµÌ£Î¹Ì£. In the
next line Wilcken is, I think, right: It is Î³Î±Ï.

not Ï€Î±ÏÎ± and Î¹Î»Î¹ÎºÎ¿Î¹ What you took
for the second half of Î is probably only
paint.
As for ÎµÏ€Î¹Î´Î±Î½ÎµÎ¹]Î¶ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ I agree with you
Î¶ is unsatisfactory. Î½]Î¹Ì£ÏƒÌ£Î±Ì£ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ could be read
but it is more like ]Î»ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹

he made a muddle of it first. Î±Î½ÎµÎ½ÎµÎ½ÎµÎ³
ÎºÎ±Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ will do. In this scrawl Î¿Î½, Ï‰Î½
and Î±Î½ are indistinguishable, but ÏƒÏ…Î½Ï„Î±Î³Î¸Î·Î¹
wont do. I am prepared to accept M's
ÏƒÏ…Î½Ï„Î±ÏƒÏƒÎ·Î¹
(1b) He seems to have written Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ·
first (perhaps he was going to write Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±Î½)
and then scratched out Î¿Ï… & put in Î¿ at
the top á¼¡ Ï…Î³Î¹Î·Ï‚ is right. In the
next line Ï€ÏÎ¿Ì£Ï‚Ì£ Ï„Ì£Î±Ì£ Î¸Ì£ÎµÎ¼ÎµÎ»Îµ Ï„Î·Ï‚ can be

read. He certainly didnt write Î¸ÎµÎ¼ÎµÎ»Î¹Î±
but it is possiblye he inserted Î± over the
line aftewrads, for the papyrus is rubbed
just at that point
(4) II xx col I 15 Î¿]Î¸Ì£ÎµÌ£Î½ is right.
(5) II xxii 14. about 10 letters are lost
between Ï‡Ï…ÏÎ±ÏƒÎ·Ì£Î¹Ì£ and Î±Ï€Î¿. I cant see
any ÎµÎ¹.
(6) XXVI (4) 2. the traces before Î¿Ï‚ will
do for Î·Î¼. Î›Î¹Î¼Î½Î±Î¹Î¿Ï… of course is
right as in (3) 2,3 Î»Î¹/Î¼Î½Î±Î¹Î¿Ï… Ï„Î¿Ï… Ï€Î±ÏÎ±
In (7) I should read ğ…‚ Î± Ï‡Î±Î»ÎºÎ¿Ï…
[Î´Ï]Î±Ï‡Î¼Î±[Ï‚ Îµ?Î¾|Î·ÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„Î±. But I dont
understand lines 5 and 6 where M's readings
must be wrong. I suspect a mention
of Î±ÏÎ³Ï…ÏÎ¹Î¿Î½ in line 6. L.6. in (8)
too there was probably a payment in both

silver & copper. There are traces of
a line below Î±ÏÎ³ ğ…‚ ÎµÎºÎ±[Ï„Î¿Î½.
Ptolemais á½…ÏÎ¼Î¿Ï… is by the way
almost certainly at Illahun. Probably
the Gurob papyri came from its very
cemetery.
Our boxes have come. Petrie tells me
he only found about 25 papyrus mummies.
We have parts of 120 (about 60 well
preserved), so our collection ought to be
very large, though the pectorals etc are in
most cases somewhat smaller than the Gurob
ones.
Tell Mahaffy I am very sorry he wouldnt
come here.
